did.unittitle: University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee Libraries, Office of the Director Records, 1885-2014

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee Libraries. Office of the Director

physdesc.label: Quantity
physdesc.extent: 28.6 cubic ft. (49 boxes, including 15 audio reels, 16 audio cassettes, and 23 videocassettes)
plus additions of 56 cubic ft. (61 boxes), 1 oversize folder, 2693 digital text files, 2 C-type videotapes, and 2 1-inch videotapes

extref.corpname: University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee Libraries, Archives Department

did.abstract: The collection contains records of the director of the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee Libraries and its predecessor institutions, the Library of the Wisconsin State Teachers College, the Kenwood Library, and the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee Library. The records document the development of automated cataloging and circulation systems at the library. Includes extensive files on the university's Telecommunications Task Force, which made recommendations regarding telecommunications strategy, planning, and acquisitions. The collection also contains records documenting the development of the library's physical plant, the Morris Fromkin Memorial Lecture Series, the Friends of the Library organization and the Staff Association, correspondence with donors of materials, and accession and withdrawal books from the main library of the Normal School and State Teachers College and from specialized libraries. The collection contains little documentation concerning the operations within the library. There are some files concerning the American Geographical Society, Cataloging Department, Technical Services, and the Curriculum Library, and there are miscellaneous annual reports from some of the other departments within the library. Also included are various publications and guides produced by library departments, relating to collections and exhibits.

bioghist.p: The university library was formed by the combination of the libraries of the Milwaukee Extension and the Milwaukee State Teachers College after the creation of UWM in 1956. In the early years of the university, the main campus library was the Kenwood Library, housed in what became Mellencamp Hall. As early as 1958, Donald Woods, director of the library, and the Library Committee foresaw the need for expanding the physical facilities of the library and suggested the site of Baker Field House. Although Kenwood Library underwent remodeling in the early 1960s, the need for additional space remained unsolved as the student population of UWM continued to grow. A new library building was planned and constructed in the mid 1960s and the library materials were moved to the new facility in February 1967. Stage II of the library, completed in 1974, and Stage III, completed in 1987, were constructed to provide additional facilities. The library was renamed the Golda Meir Library in 1979. In 2002, the administrative name of the library as a unit was changed to UWM Libraries.

chronitem.event: Donald Woods (formerly Director of the State Teachers College Library)

bioghist.p: William Moritz served as Interim Director after the administrations of Gormley and Roselle.

The library's mission is to make information available for research in a wide range of fields by undergraduates, graduate students, and faculty. The various departments of the library assist in making the library's holdings accessible. The American Geographical Society, founded in 1851 in New York, moved its library and map collections to the library in 1978. Technical Services is responsible for identifying materials to be added to the library collections and processing these materials for use. The Cataloging Department, a division within Technical Services, has the specific responsibility for classifying and cataloging materials before they are added to the holdings. Interlibrary Loan obtains library materials which are held by other libraries to aid students and faculty in their research. The Archives Department collects and provides reference to materials documenting the activities of UWM. The Milwaukee Area Research Center, created in 1963 by agreement between the Wisconsin Historical Society (WHS) and UWM, provides access to archival and manuscript collections owned by the WHS. The Morris Fromkin Collection, established in 1969, focuses on the quest for social justice in the United States between the end of the Civil War and the end of the New Deal. The Curriculum Library, founded in the early 1950s as part of the State Teachers College, serves the needs of education students.

Other organizations associated with the library include the Friends of the Library and the Staff Association. The Friends of the Library, a group founded to encourage donations to the UWM Library, formed in 1961. In 1964, the group became the Library Associates, and assumed its former name, Friends of the Library, in the 1970s. The group took its current name, Friends of the Golda Meir Library, in 1979. The Staff Association, officially known as the UWM Library Staff Association, appears to have been a continuation of an organization from the State Teachers College since its records predate the establishment of UWM. It is managed by a committee of staff members and conducts social activities for the staff.

scopecontent.p: The collection contains records of the director of the UWM Libraries and its predecessor institutions, the Library of the Wisconsin State Teachers College, the Kenwood Library, the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee Library, and the Golda Meir Library. Most of the records date from 1970 to 1985. The only records predating 1940 are accession and withdrawal books, annual reports, and statistical reports prepared for the American Library Association.

The records largely document the development of automated cataloging and circulation systems at the library. Numerous files throughout the collection pertain to automation. Policy decisions regarding automation planning and implementation can be found in the files of the "Cataloging Department," "Committee on Automated Library Services," "Library Administrative Committee," and "Library Executive Committee." Of particular interest for its detail is the 1973 report, Library Automation at the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee. The report, by Director William Roselle and Susan Hess, head of library automated operations, was written for the Library Automation Research and Consulting (LARC) Association.

The collection contains little documentation concerning operations within the library. There are some files concerning the American Geographical Society, Cataloging Department, Technical Services, and the Curriculum Library, and miscellaneous annual reports from some of the other departments within the library.

The collection contains extensive files on the university's Telecommunications Task Force, of which William Roselle was chair. The task force, consisting of sixteen campus faculty and administrators appointed in 1982 by Chancellor Frank Horton, examined and described developments and opportunities in the area of telecommunications, and made recommendations regarding telecommunications strategy, planning, and acquisitions for a ten year period. The files contain background materials, meeting agendas and minutes, and reports of the task force.

The development of the physical plant at the UWM Libraries is documented in the files on "Building Data," "Building Program," "Library Administrative Committee," "Library Building Committee," "Library Decorating Committee," "Library Executive Committee," and the "Sculpture in the Library Court."

The files on the Morris Fromkin Memorial Lecture Series include background correspondence, advertising materials including posters, transcripts, some sound recordings, and a videotape of the annual lecture.

The accession books contain the oldest records in the collection, dating to 1885. Most of the books are from the main Library of the Normal School and State Teachers College, but there are some from the specialized libraries as well, including the Parent-Teacher Library, and the Training School Library. The origin of several of the accession books cannot be identified. The collection contains withdrawal books from two specialized libraries, the Elementary Reference Library and the Text-Book Library.

There are numerous files on the Friends of the Library organization and the Staff Association, including by-laws, correspondence, information on their activities, meeting agendas and minutes, membership lists, and newsletters.

Correspondence with donors of materials to the library is incomplete and scattered throughout the collection. Information on major donors can be found under their name; other donors may be located in the records on money gifts and the miscellaneous files.

Newsletters and other publications of the Libraries can be found under their title. The collection also contains a small number of resource guides and exhibition publications, which are listed by short title of the exhibition or by the name of the producing department.

arrangement.p: This collection was received in, and is organized in, multiple parts. Additional materials have not been physically or intellectually arranged and interfiled, and researchers may need to consult more than one part of the collection to locate similar materials.
The collection contains a number of additional accessions.

otherfindaid.p: Inventories of the personnel files in boxes 23-25 and of accessions 1999-059, 2005-007, 2006-016, and 2006-070 are available in the Archives' case file.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material in the UWM Libraries

accessrestrict.p: The unclassified personnel files in boxes 23-25, accession 1999-059, and box 18 of accession 2006-070 are restricted in accordance with UWM Personnel File Policy S-42. Access is regulated by Section III.A.2 and III.A.3.
There are no access restrictions on the rest of the collection, which is open to all members of the public in accordance with state law.

userestrict.p: The researcher assumes full responsibility for conforming with the laws of libel, privacy, and copyright which may be involved in the use of this collection (Wisconsin Statutes 19.21-19.39).

acqinfo.p: The provenance of the records is unclear. Many of the records in the collection were created or compiled by the director and various members of the library staff. It is not known if particular records were brought together by the director or if they were separated from other files by library or archives staff. The records, whatever their provenance, were placed together under the library by the Archives Department staff sometime before 1989. When reprocessing began in 1993, it was decided to leave the existing organization intact rather than to possibly confuse the provenance even more. The library transferred another accession (accession 1992-030) in April 1993. Several items from the 1993 Fromkin Lecture were added to the collection in February 1994. Boxes 26-27 (accession 1996-027) were added in March 1997. Accession 1996-040 was transferred in April 1997; accession 1996-047 in May 1997; and accession 2002-029 in May 2002. The Office of the Director transferred a small amount of material to the Archives in August 2008. The Assistant to the Director transferred accession 2008-022 to the Archives in October 2008. Materials transferred piecemeal from the Director's Office in 2008-2010 were retroactively converted to accessions 2008-042, 2009-023, 2009-024, and 2009-050 in March 2010. Linda Kopp transferred accession 1998-055 in January 1998. Dawn Lee-Vue transferred accession 2005-007 in August 2005, accession 2006-070 in June 2007, accession 2007-007 in July 2007, and accession 2011-008 in Aguust 2011. The UWM Libraries transferred accession 2011-033 in January 2012 and accession 2013-010 in August 2013. Accession 2010-045 was transferred by an unknown individual in April 2011. Accession 2012-044 was transferred by an unknown individual in February 2013. Tim Ericson, Assistant Library Director for Archives and Special Collections, transferred accession 2000-037 in January 2000. Michael Doylen transferred accession 2015-030 to the Archives in late 2015.

processinfo.p: Kevin Corbitt processed parts of the collection in 1991. Mark A. Vargas processed twenty-four processed and unprocessed series in March through April 1993. Larry Kellneor processed boxes 26-27 in March 1997. Christel Maass added accessions 1996-040 and 1996-047 in October 1997 (boxes 28-29). Leslie Heinrichs and Charles Kempker processed box 34 in May 2002. Jeremy Brett added 1999-059 and 2003-092 (personnel files) to the collection in November 2006. Brad Houston added some material from the Archives 'dribble file' in August 2008. Allen Ramsey added accession 2008-022 to the collection in June 2009 (Brad Houston supervised). Brad Houston added some additional material from the 'dribble file' in September 2009 and in January 2010. Charles Welborn processed additional material from the 'dribble file' in August 2012. Hayley Jackson updated the finding aid to include information about accessions 1998-055, 1999-059, 2005-007, 2006-016, 2006-070, 2007-007, 2009-014, 2009-023, 2009-024, 2009-050, 2010-045, 2011-008, 2011-033, 2012-022, 2012-044, and 2013-010 in November 2014. Brad Houston supervised processing of accessions 2008-042 and part of 2009-050 between 2012-2013. Brad Houston processed additional material in December 2014. Christel Maass processed accession 2000-037 in May 2015 (boxes 47-48). Christel Maass minimally processed accession 2015-030 in February 2016. Christel Maass separated AV materials from amid the paper records in January 2017. Brad Houston completed processing accession 2009-050 in January 2017.

In November 2009, the name of the collection was changed from Golda Meir Library, Office of the Director to University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee Libraries, Office of the Director to reflect the office's most recent official name.

did.abstract: Additions largely consisting of memos, budget planning files, and NLS/NOTIS files, dating from 1990 to 1998.
Additions of personnel files closed before 2005.

Additions containing materials concerning the establishment of the Fromkin Memorial Collection, Fromkin lecture applications and proposals, and correspondence concerning Fromkin book. Files date from 1969 to 2001.
Additions including Friends records, holiday cards, affirmative action evaluation, exhibits and program files, Staff Development Committee, and Staff Advisory Council files, dating from 1982 to 2000.
Additions of administrative files, largely dating from 1980 to 2004.
Additions of minutes for the Friends, Staff Advisory Council, and the University Library Committee. Also includes a file pertaining to the library strategic plan. Files date from 1994 to 2001.
Additions of photographs and ephemera dating from 1963 to 2007. Includes pamphlets and mailings advertising library events, and a few early architectural drawings of Stage I of the library.

Additions of miscellaneous files, dating from 1970 to 1998. Includes files on Fromkin and Hardie gifts (with associated agreements and correspondence), some files on the Phase III building project, and some publicity materials. Also included are numerous unique Friends of the Library newsletters, as well as photographs of events between 1980 and 1998.
Additions of Daniel Soref Learning Commons artwork and an oversize exterior photo of the library. Materials are from 2007 and undated.
Additions of administrative files largely dating from 1991 to 2008.
Additions of administrative files, including materials focusing on planning and budget, dating from 1988 to 2005.
Additions of miscellaneous AGSL-related publications. Also includes AGSL contracts and founding documents. Materials date from 1976 to 1990.
Additions of miscellaneous materials, including planning documents, staff newsletters, chrono files, remodeling, and user survey files.

Additions of emails from Peter Watson-Boone dating from 1997 to 2003. Includes correspondence relating to several functions of Watson-Boone's tenure as Library Director, including communication with library and campus units and correspondence relating to his participation in CUWL. Some materials also relate to personnel matters and are restricted.
Additions of video of the dedication of the Golda Meir Library in 1979.

Additions of records pertaining to the Fromkin lecture series, dating from 1969 to 2002. Includes information about the establishment of the Fromkin collection, correspondence, proposals, copies of lectures, guides to sources in the Fromkin collection and the Archives, as well as some materials pertaining to the Quest for Social Justice, volumes I and II.
